program.name: 0test
program.author: Thomas Leonard
program.p: A Zero Install feed can specify a command to run to test the program automatically using the self-test attribute. 0test runs this command. It can also test combinations of various versions of a program and its dependencies.

html.p: Create a short-cut to it in the usual way:
Most simply, you can use it to run the tests for a program you have downloaded or checked out of version control. e.g.
You can also use it to test released programs, e.g. to test the default version of 0compile:
You can specify a particular set of versions to test:
html.pre: $ 0test http://0install.net/2006/interfaces/0compile.xml 0.20 0.21 Passed - 0compile v0.20, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6, 0publish v0.17 Skipped - 0compile v(none) None failed
html.p: A summary is printed at the end showing the result of each combination:

dl.dd: the tests all passed successfully (the command returned an exit status of zero)
this combination of versions can't be used together (or no tests are defined)
some tests failed (the self-test command returned a non-zero exit status)

html.p: You can specify versions of libraries the program depends on too. 0test will try all combinations. This tests three versions of 0compile against three versions of Zero Install (a total of 3 x 3 = 9 tests):
html.pre: $ 0test --html results.html \ http://0install.net/2006/interfaces/0compile.xml 0.19 0.20 0.20-post \ http://0install.net/2007/interfaces/ZeroInstall.xml 0.47 0.48 0.48-post Passed - 0compile v0.20, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.20, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48-post, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.20-post, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.20-post, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48-post, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post Skipped - 0compile v0.20-post, ZeroInstall-Injector v(none), ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post Failed - 0compile v0.19, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.47, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.19, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.19, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.48-post, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post - 0compile v0.20, ZeroInstall-Injector v0.47, ROX-Lib2 v2.0.6-post, 0publish v0.17-post
html.p: The --html results.html option causes it to also generate this table:
Green = Passed, Red = Failed, Yellow = Skipped. The contents of the cells show the versions of components used in the tests where you didn't specify the version (so 0test selected one for you).

We can see in this example that the unit-tests for 0compile 0.19 no longer pass, regardless of the version of Zero Install used. This problem was caused by a change to the GNU-Hello test program it uses within its own tests. Ideally, programs should depend on their test data using <requires interface="..." use="testing">, but 0compile actually needed to test downloading of the test code itself. 0compile 0.20 fails with older version of Zero Install due to a bug in the way "0launch --get-selections" generated the XML. 0compile 0.20-post depends on a later version explicitly, so the broken combination is skipped.
If you specify a test matrix with more than two dimensions, 0test will generate a series of tables.

The --test-command option can be used to run the command of your choice, rather than the test command given in the feed's self-test attribute. The path of the program's main executable is available as $1.
For example, to check that "rox --version" worked in versions 2.8 and 2.9 of ROX-Filer:
html.pre: $ 0test -t '$1 --version > /dev/null' \ http://rox.sourceforge.net/2005/interfaces/ROX-Filer 2.8 2.9 Passed - ROX-Filer v2.8 - ROX-Filer v2.9 None skipped None failed
html.p: Dependencies marked with use="testing" in their feed are normally ignored by 0launch. However, when using 0test they are enabled.
This allows you to add extra dependencies that are only used when testing your program. For example, you can use this to depend on a testing framework or a large test data-set:
html.pre: <group self-test="tests/testall.py"> <requires interface="http://example.com/somelib.xml"> ... </requires> <requires interface="http://testing.com/testframework.xml" use="testing"> <environment insert="" mode="replace" name="TEST_FRAMEWORK"/> </requires> <implementation id="." version="0.1-pre"/> </group>
html.p: Note: 0launch < 0.43 doesn't know about the use attribute and will include the dependency in all cases.
